Award.AwardTitle: Supports for learning to manage classroom discussions: Exploring the role of practical rationality and mathematical knowledge for teaching

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at the Universities of Michigan and Maryland are developing materials to survey the rationality behind secondary mathematics teaching practice and to support the development by secondary mathematics preservice teachers of specialized knowledge and skills for teaching. The project focuses on the leading of classroom discussions for the learning of algebra and geometry.

Using animations of instructional scenarios, the project is developing online, multimedia questionnaires and using them to assess practicing teachers' mathematical knowledge for teaching and their evaluations of teacher decision making. Reports and forum entries from the questionnaires are integrated into a learning environment for prospective teachers and their instructors built around these animated scenarios. This environment allows pre-service teachers to navigate, annotate, and communicate about the scenarios; and it allows their instructors to plan using those scenarios and share experiences with their counterparts.

The research on teachers' rationality uses an experimental design with embedded one-way ANOVA, while the development of the learning environment uses a process of iterative design, implementation, and evaluation. The project evaluation by researchers at Northwestern University uses qualitative methods to examine the content provided in the environment as well as the usefulness perceived by teacher educators of a state network and their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has explored rich media strategies for representing classroom scenarios in the service of assessments of the kinds of social resources that high school math and science teachers use for making instructional decisions. The project has shown that scenarios using storyboards (or sequences of graphic panels where teacher and students are enacted by cartoon characters) can immerse teachers in practice and elicit responses that add greatly to the information about practice often collected through traditional surveys.

 

Methodologically, the project has operationalized the concepts of instructional norm and professional obligation as social resources for teachers and has created 29 scenario-based assessments, as well as 5 survey instruments to elicit data from teachers, then used such data to examine measures associated with the concepts of instructional norm and professional obligation. The project developed a measure of mathematical knowledge for teaching geometry to be used along with existing measures of mathematical knowledge for teaching algebra and measures of teachers? beliefs. The project also developed a suite of 4 decision making instruments that put practitioners in the position of having to decide what to do next.

 

The project collected data with these assessments, surveys, and measures from a national representative sample of 689 secondary mathematics teachers from 47 states. Findings include that while teachers expect a geometry teacher to provide proof problems completely formulated for students (with a given, to prove, and diagram), they approve of scenarios in which the teacher provides opportunities for students to participate in problem formulation. Similarly, while teachers approve of mathematically correct student solutions to equations that use alternative methods, they find them significantly less appropriate than those that use canonical methods; while they would spend time discussing alternative methods, they describe their responsibility as algebra teachers as teaching students to solve equations using a particular method that consists of deploying particular steps in a particular order. More findings have been reported in over 40 publications produced by the team thus far and secondary analysis of the collected data is ongoing. Combined, the analyses portray a complicated picture of what influences teacher decisions--while individual factors such as teacher knowledge do impact what teachers choose to do in specific instances--their recognition of instructional norms, and perceptions of obligations incumbent on them as teachers, also play nontrivial roles.

 

To support the development and distribution of a set of connected scenario-based assessments, the team developed the LessonSketch platform. This platform contains a variety of authoring tools with which researchers can create storyboards and questionnaires and which teacher educators can use for other purposes. Since its publication in 2011, the platform has been subscribed by more than 8000 users, who include classroom teachers, teacher educators, preservice teachers, and education researchers. The platform has served for the administration of the instruments created by this project, and has been reused in at least 3 other research and development projects.
